hanzi-su-wiki:
賜

Значения

Быть одаренным, получать дар; жаловать, дарить

Мнемоника

Ценный подарок. Его можно легко 易 поменять на деньги 貝.

Варианты

赐
purpleculture_pinyin:
cì
to confer; to bestow; to grant
для придания; дарить; наградить
rtega_mnemonic:
賜賜RS
赐赐		give, bestow favours, appoint
  • pouring 易 money 貝 like water: give away
purpleculture_info:
(Simplified: 赐)
Antonyms: 乞
Pictophonetic: 易 indicates the sound; 貝 (money) conveys the meaning.
purpleculture_examples:
賜予 [ cì yǔ ]: to grant; to bestow
賜福 [ cì fú ]: to bless

• ⿰ Left to right

    • 易 [ yì ] to change; to exchange, to trade; simple, easy

koohiiStory2: Do you want free shells from the government? It´s easy with my new book, "How to Get a Free Grant from the Government!" Call today!
kunYomi: たまわ.る、たま.う、たも.う
jp_example_words: 賜る(たまわる): to grant, to bestow
Ru_Radicals: ハ, 日 (день), 勿 (конечно), 目 (глаз), 貝 (раковина)
Ru_trainchinese: cì: (глаг/сущ) жаловать, удостаивать, даровать; (вежл.) милость, дар
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the shellfish (貝) finds it easy (易) to get a grant
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Nothing exemplifies easy shells better than a student grant for going to university.
humanum_full_description_en:
" Gi " starts with " Bei ", " Yi " sound, " Yi " doubles as a sign. " Yi " is an ancient word for " gi ", and both Oracle and Bronze inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty use " yi " as " gi ". " Yi " is simplified from " Yi " (Guo Moruo), which means that the wealth of the rewarded person has increased (see " Yi " for details). In the Spring and Autumn Period, the word " gives " began to appear, and " bei " was added next to " yi " as a sign, which clearly means to give property, the original meaning is to give and reward. "Shuowen": "Give, give. Congbei, Yisheng."

Bronze writing is used as the original meaning. Geng Yu: "Yutai (Yi) bestows her (you)." It means I reward you. Also used as a name. The king of the Yue Kingdom is to give the bell: "The king of the Hu (Yue) is to give it", "Zhezhi" means "Zhu Ji". During the Warring States Period, "Yu Ci" was the name; "Zhu Ji Yu Ci" was "Historical Records. Yue Wang, also known as Luying, mentioned in Yue Wang Jujian Family, is the eldest son of Yue Wang Jujian.

Warring States bamboo slips are used as the original meaning. "Tsinghua Jane III. " Said Mingshang" Jane 1: "Only the king of Yin gave (saying) to the sky." " Say " is Fu said, the minister of Wuding of the Yin king; this sentence refers to the gods who bestowed Fu said to Wuding. "Shangbo Bamboo Book III. "Rong Chengshi" Jane 33: "Qi (their) gives birth to (raise), and Qi (their) death grants burial." It means that (Gao Tao) gives education to the living people and gives burial to the dead people.

Han silk is used as the original meaning. "Mawangdui Silk Book. "Warring States Political Strategist Book" line 40: "The king used to forgive his ministers, and the ministers were given gifts." It means that the monarch forgives his subjects' sins and the subjects accept the reward.

" Gift " is derived from the meaning of reward as a favor or property to a person. "Mandarin. "Jin Yu": "Repaying one's life with death, and repaying with strength." Wei Zhao's note: "Gift, benefit also." This sentence refers to repaying (the king's father) with death to make him live, and repaying (the king's father) with labor. grace. It was extended to exempt. "Han Shu. "Shihuo Zhi 1": "Shangfu follows its words, which is half of the twelve-year tax granted to the people by the Xia Zhao." This sentence means that Emperor Wu of the Han Dynasty obeyed Chao Cuo's words and issued the edict to exempt the people from the twelve-year farmland tax. Half of it.

The handed down documents use " tin " as the " gift ." "Shang Shu. "Hong Fan": "Heaven is Xiyu Hongfan Jiuchou." It means that the heaven bestows Yu Yu on nine ways to control floods.
humanum_short_description_en: The original meaning of " gives " is to give and reward treasures.
humanum_full_description:
「賜」從「貝」，「易」聲，「易」兼作意符。「易」為「賜」的古字，甲骨文和西周金文皆以「易」為「賜」。「易」由「益」簡化而來（郭沫若），表示受賞賜的人財富有所增加（詳見「易」字）。春秋始有「賜」字，在「易」旁加上「貝」為意符，明確表示賜予財物，本義為給予、賞賜。《說文》：「賜，予也。从貝，易聲。」

　　金文用作本義。庚壼：「余台（以）賜女（汝）。」表示我賞賜你。又用作人名。越王者旨於賜鐘：「戉（越）王者旨於賜」，「者旨」即「諸稽」，戰國時越國宗室之姓氏，「於賜」是名；「諸稽於賜」就是《史記．越王句踐世家》提及的鼫與，又名鹿郢，即是越王句踐的長子。

　　戰國竹簡用作本義。《清華簡三．說命上》簡1：「惟殷王賜敓（說）于天。」「說」即傅說，殷王武丁的大臣；這句指上天把傅說賜給武丁。《上博竹書三．容成氏》簡33：「亓（其）生賜羕（養）也，亓（其）死賜葬。」意指（皋陶）對在生的百姓給予教養，對逝去的百姓給予厚葬。

　　漢帛書用作本義。《馬王堆帛書．戰國縱橫家書》第40行：「而王以赦臣，臣受賜矣。」意謂君主赦免臣子的罪，臣子接受這個賞賜。

　　「賜」由賞賜義引申作給人的恩惠或財物。《國語．晉語》：「報生以死，報賜以力。」韋昭注：「賜，惠也。」這句指以死報答（君父）使之生存，以勞力報答（君父）給予的恩惠。又引申解作免除。《漢書．食貨志上》：「上復從其言，乃下詔賜民十二年租稅之半。」這句意指漢武帝聽從晁錯之言，下詔書免去百姓十二年農田租稅的一半。

　　傳世文獻以「錫」為「賜」。《尚書．洪範》：「天乃錫禹洪範九疇。」意謂上天賜予大禹治理洪水的九個方法。

English Definition: to confer; to bestow; to grant

    • 易 [ yì ] to change; to exchange, to trade; simple, easy
Example Words:

賜福 [ cì fú ]: to bless
More: 賜* | *賜 | *賜*

「 賜 」從「 貝 」，「 易 」聲，「 易 」兼作意符。「 易 」為「 賜 」的古字，甲骨文和西周金文皆以「 易 」為「 賜 」。「 易 」由「 益 」簡化而來（郭沫若），表示受賞賜的人財富有所增加（詳見「 易 」字）。春秋始有「 賜 」字，在「 易 」旁加上「 貝 」為意符，明確表示賜予財物，本義為給予、賞賜。《說文》：「賜，予也。从貝，易聲。」 金文用作本義。庚壼：「余台（以）賜女（汝）。」表示我賞賜你。又用作人名。越王者旨於賜鐘：「戉（越）王者旨於賜」，「者旨」即「諸稽」，戰國時越國宗室之姓氏，「於賜」是名；「諸稽於賜」就是《史記．越王句踐世家》提及的鼫與，又名鹿郢，即是越王句踐的長子。 戰國竹簡用作本義。《清華簡三．說命上》簡1：「惟殷王賜敓（說）于天。」「 說 」即傅說，殷王武丁的大臣；這句指上天把傅說賜給武丁。《上博竹書三．容成氏》簡33：「亓（其）生賜羕（養）也，亓（其）死賜葬。」意指（皋陶）對在生的百姓給予教養，對逝去的百姓給予厚葬。 漢帛書用作本義。《馬王堆帛書．戰國縱橫家書》第40行：「而王以赦臣，臣受賜矣。」意謂君主赦免臣子的罪，臣子接受這個賞賜。 「 賜 」由賞賜義引申作給人的恩惠或財物。《國語．晉語》：「報生以死，報賜以力。」韋昭注：「賜，惠也。」這句指以死報答（君父）使之生存，以勞力報答（君父）給予的恩惠。又引申解作免除。《漢書．食貨志上》：「上復從其言，乃下詔賜民十二年租稅之半。」這句意指漢武帝聽從晁錯之言，下詔書免去百姓十二年農田租稅的一半。 傳世文獻以「 錫 」為「 賜 」。《尚書．洪範》：「天乃錫禹洪範九疇。」意謂上天賜予大禹治理洪水的九個方法。
" Gi" starts with " Bei", " Yi" sound, " Yi" doubles as a sign. " Yi" is an ancient word for " gi", and both Oracle and Bronze inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty use " yi" as " gi". " Yi" is simplified from " Yi" (Guo Moruo), which means that the wealth of the rewarded person has increased (see " Yi" for details). In the Spring and Autumn Period, the word " gives" began to appear, and " bei" was added next to " yi" as a sign, which clearly means to give property, the original meaning is to give and reward. "Shuowen": "Give, give. Congbei, Yisheng." Bronze writing is used as the original meaning. Geng Yu: "Yutai (Yi) bestows her (you)." It means I reward you. Also used as a name. The king of the Yue Kingdom is to give the bell: "The king of the Hu (Yue) is to give it", "Zhezhi" means "Zhu Ji". During the Warring States Period, "Yu Ci" was the name; "Zhu Ji Yu Ci" was "Historical Records. Yue Wang, also known as Luying, mentioned in Yue Wang Jujian Family, is the eldest son of Yue Wang Jujian. Warring States bamboo slips are used as the original meaning. "Tsinghua Jane III. " Said Mingshang" Jane 1: "Only the king of Yin gave (saying) to the sky." " Say" is Fu said, the minister of Wuding of the Yin king; this sentence refers to the gods who bestowed Fu said to Wuding. "Shangbo Bamboo Book III. "Rong Chengshi" Jane 33: "Qi (their) gives birth to (raise), and Qi (their) death grants burial." It means that (Gao Tao) gives education to the living people and gives burial to the dead people. Han silk is used as the original meaning. "Mawangdui Silk Book. "Warring States Political Strategist Book" line 40: "The king used to forgive his ministers, and the ministers were given gifts." It means that the monarch forgives his subjects' sins and the subjects accept the reward. " Gift" is derived from the meaning of reward as a favor or property to a person. "Mandarin. "Jin Yu": "Repaying one's life with death, and repaying with strength." Wei Zhao's note: "Gift, benefit also." This sentence refers to repaying (the king's father) with death to make him live, and repaying (the king's father) with labor. grace. It was extended to exempt. "Han Shu. "Shihuo Zhi 1": "Shangfu follows its words, which is half of the twelve-year tax granted to the people by the Xia Zhao." This sentence means that Emperor Wu of the Han Dynasty obeyed Chao Cuo's words and issued the edict to exempt the people from the twelve-year farmland tax. Half of it. The handed down documents use " tin" as the " gift." "Shang Shu. "Hong Fan": "Heaven is Xiyu Hongfan Jiuchou." It means that the heaven bestows Yu Yu on nine ways to control floods.

賜字的基本解释

賜
cì
见“赐”。

賜字的汉语字典释义

[①]［cì］
［《廣韻》斯義切，去寘，心。］
“赐1”的繁体字。
(1)赏赐，给予。
(2)用作敬辞。敬称对方的给予。
(3)给人的恩惠或财物。
(4)对帝王下达旨意的敬称。
(5)蠲免。
(6)穷尽。后多作“儩”。
(7)通“私”。偏私。
(8)姓。

賜字的康熙字典解释

【酉集中】【貝字部】　賜； 康熙笔画：15； 页码：页1209第15
【唐韻】【集韻】【韻會】?斯義切，思去聲。【說文】予也。【篇海】錫也。【禮·曲禮】三賜不及車馬。【註】三賜，三命也。【疏】受命卽受賜。又【玉藻】凡賜，君子與小人不同日。　又【公羊傳·僖二年】虞郭之相救，非相爲賜。【註】賜，猶惠也。　又【玉篇】賜，施也，空盡也。　又姓。【玉海】齊大夫?子賜之後。　【正字通】俗作?，非。

賜字的源字形

字源演变：

金文小篆楷体

字形对比：

中国大陆宋体台湾细明体香港明体日本明朝体韩国明朝体旧字形
賜字的起名意思

暂无。

Basic explanation of words
Give
cì
See "Gi".
Give
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[①]［cì］
["Guangyun" cut righteously, set, heart. ]
Traditional Chinese characters for "给1".
(1) Reward, give.
(2) Used as a respectful speech. Respect the other party's giving.
(3) Favors or possessions given to people.
(4) The honorific title given to the emperor's will.
(5) Exemption.
(6) Exhaustion. Later, "儩" is often used.
(7) Through "private". Partiality.
(8) Last name.
Give
Kangxi dictionary interpretation of words
[Unitary Collection] [Beijing Department] 　ci; Kangxi Strokes: 15; Page Number: Page 1209 No. 15
[Tang Yun] [Ji Yun] [Rhyme Meeting]? Si Yiqie, think about it. [Said the text] I also. [Article Sea] Tin also. 【Ritual·Courtesy】Three gifts are not as good as carriages and horses. [Note] Three gifts, three destinies. 【Sparse】received and given. Also 【Yuzao】Every gift, a gentleman is different from a villain.　[Gongyang Zhuan·Xi 2 Years] Yu Guo's rescue is not a gift. [Note] Thanks, you still benefit.　[Jade articles] Give, give, and empty.　Another last name. [Yuhai] Doctor Qi? After Zici.　[Zhengzitong] popular writing?, no.
